{
  "concepts": [
    {"term": "distributions", "category": "mathematics"},
    {"term": "overlap", "category": "mathematics"},
    {"term": "threshold", "category": "algorithm"},
    {"term": "false negatives", "category": "quality_metric"},
    {"term": "false positives", "category": "quality_metric"},
    {"term": "decision threshold", "category": "algorithm"},
    {"term": "ROC curve", "category": "algorithm"},
    {"term": "sensitivity", "category": "quality_metric"},
    {"term": "specificity", "category": "quality_metric"}
  ],
  "evidence": [
    "Most of the time, the distributions of healthy and diseased patients overlap.",
    "a threshold placed in the middle will inevitably create two types of errors.",
    "So when the two distributions overlap, a threshold placed in the middle will inevitably create two types of errors.",
    "And it’s what makes tools like the ROC curve so valuable, because they let us analyze the trade-off between sensitivity and specificity across all possible thresholds."
  ]

evidence: Most of the time, the distributions of healthy and diseased patients overlap.
a threshold placed in the middle will inevitably create two types of errors.
So when the two distributions overlap, a threshold placed in the middle will inevitably create two types of errors.
And it’s what makes tools like the ROC curve so valuable, because they let us analyze the trade-off between sensitivity and specificity across all possible thresholds.
